subtopics.title: Introduction to Quadrilaterals
subtopics.content:
Introduction

In geometry, polygons are closed figures formed by line segments. A quadrilateral is a special polygon with four sides, four vertices, and four angles. Quadrilaterals are everywhere around us — in windows, tables, books, tiles, and even in playing cards. Studying quadrilaterals helps us understand their shapes, properties, and how they are classified.

subtopics.title: Polygons
subtopics.content:
Polygon Basics

A polygon is a closed figure made up of line segments.

Examples: triangle (3 sides), quadrilateral (4 sides), pentagon (5 sides), hexagon (6 sides), etc.

Convex Polygon: All interior angles < 180°.

Concave Polygon: At least one angle > 180°.

subtopics.title: Quadrilaterals Overview
subtopics.content:
Quadrilateral Properties

A quadrilateral has:

  • 4 sides
  • 4 vertices
  • 4 angles

Sum of interior angles = 360°

subtopics.title: Types of Quadrilaterals - Parallelogram
subtopics.content:
Parallelogram

  • Opposite sides are parallel and equal.
  • Opposite angles are equal.
  • Diagonals bisect each other.

subtopics.title: Types of Quadrilaterals - Rectangle
subtopics.content:
Rectangle

  • A parallelogram with all angles = 90°.
  • Diagonals are equal and bisect each other.

subtopics.title: Types of Quadrilaterals - Square
subtopics.content:
Square

  • A rectangle with all sides equal.
  • Diagonals are equal and bisect at right angles.

subtopics.title: Types of Quadrilaterals - Rhombus
subtopics.content:
Rhombus

  • A parallelogram with all sides equal.
  • Diagonals bisect at right angles (but not equal).

subtopics.title: Types of Quadrilaterals - Trapezium
subtopics.content:
Trapezium (Trapezoid)

  • One pair of opposite sides is parallel.

questions.question: The sum of the interior angles of a quadrilateral is:
questions.explanation: The sum of interior angles of any quadrilateral is always 360°.

questions.question: A quadrilateral with one pair of parallel sides is:
questions.explanation: A trapezium (or trapezoid) is defined as a quadrilateral with exactly one pair of parallel sides.

questions.question: In a parallelogram, opposite angles are:
questions.explanation: One of the key properties of a parallelogram is that opposite angles are equal.

questions.question: The diagonals of a rectangle are:
questions.explanation: In a rectangle, the diagonals are equal in length and bisect each other, but they are not necessarily perpendicular.

questions.question: Which quadrilateral has all sides equal but angles not 90°?
questions.explanation: A rhombus has all sides equal, but its angles are not necessarily 90°. A square has all sides equal and all angles 90°.

questions.question: The diagonals of a square are:
options: Equal and bisect at right angles
questions.answer: Equal and bisect at right angles
questions.explanation: In a square, the diagonals are equal in length and bisect each other at right angles (90°).

questions.question: A quadrilateral with two pairs of adjacent sides equal is:
questions.explanation: A kite is defined as a quadrilateral with two pairs of adjacent sides equal.

questions.question: If three angles are 80°, 100°, 90°, the fourth is:
questions.explanation: The sum of interior angles of a quadrilateral is 360°. So the fourth angle = 360° - (80° + 100° + 90°) = 360° - 270° = 90°.

questions.question: Which is NOT a property of a parallelogram?
questions.explanation: In a parallelogram, diagonals bisect each other but are not necessarily equal. They are equal only in special cases like rectangles and squares.

questions.question: In an isosceles trapezium:
questions.explanation: An isosceles trapezium is a trapezium where the non-parallel sides (legs) are equal in length.
